intro: Ophiorrhiza djamuensis, commonly known as the Java sandalwood, is a flowering plant native to Southeast Asia, particularly Indonesia. It belongs to the family Rubiaceae and is characterized by its small, clustered flowers and leathery, elliptical leaves. The plant is often found growing in coastal areas and disturbed soils, showcasing its adaptability to various environmental conditions. Its fruit is a capsule that splits open to release tiny seeds, aiding in its dispersal. Ophiorrhiza djamuensis plays a role in stabilizing sandy soils and is sometimes used in traditional medicine.
